title: First-Born Offspring imperfection discovered
vignette: A first-born offspring calf dedicated for the offering place is later found to have a small defect in its eye.

options.text: exchange it and use the money for offerings.
Ignore the imperfection and offering it anyway.

title: Selling a first-born offspring animal
vignette: A farmer wishes to sell his first-born offspring lamb to a neighbour before it develops an imperfection.

options.text: Prohibited until the community elder examines it.
He may sell it with stipulation of exchange.

title: Community Elder waiving his portion
vignette: The community elder declines taking the first-born offspring calf, letting the owner keep it.

options.text: Allowed; the community elder can forgo his rights.
Not permitted; first-born offspring belongs to the group of community elders.

title: Questionable gestation period
vignette: A cow gives birth slightly early, and it's unclear if the calf counts as a first-born offspring.

options.text: Treat it as first-born offspring out of doubt.
Consider it regular since gestation was short.

title: Offering an imperfect first-born offspring outside the Central Assembly Place
vignette: An ordinary person ritually prepares an imperfect first-born offspring at home.

options.text: Permitted once inspected and exchanged.
Forbidden; all first-born offspring meat must be eaten in the main city.

title: Benefit from unexchanged first-born offspring donkey
vignette: The owner uses his first-born offspring donkey for work before exchanging it with a lamb.

options.text: He may work it temporarily.
He must exchange before any use.

title: Community Elder selling first-born offspring meat
vignette: After ritual preparation, a community elder wants to sell portions of the first-born offspring for profit.

options.text: Allowed once the animal is ritually prepared.
Improper; the meat should be shared without sale.

title: Doubt if animal is first-born offspring
vignette: Records are lost, and it's unclear which lamb from the flock was born first.

options.text: Any doubtful animal is exempt from the community elder.
All potentially first-born offspring animals must be treated with special status.

title: First-Born Offspring of a new community member
vignette: A man converts after his cow gives birth. Does the calf have first-born offspring status?

options.text: Yes; the timing doesn't negate special status.
No; it was born before he joined the community agreement.

title: Using a first-born offspring for secular work
vignette: A farmer wants to plow with an perfect first-born offspring ox to avoid idleness.

options.text: Forbidden until it receives an imperfection or exchange.
Allowed if the work is brief and respectful.

title: Community Elder delays Exchange
vignette: A community elder procrastinates exchanging the first-born offspring donkey, waiting for lamb prices to drop.

options.text: Must exchange promptly despite cost.
Delay is acceptable until he can afford it.

title: Selling first-born offspring hide
vignette: After ritual preparation, the owner sells the hide of his first-born offspring calf.

options.text: Permissible; only the meat was special status.
He should not profit from any part.

title: Using first-born offspring funds for communal needs
vignette: Money from exchanged first-born offspring animals accumulates. Can it fund local infrastructure?

options.text: Yes; spending on community benefits is proper.
It should only buy other offerings.

title: First-Born Offspring born by caesarean
vignette: A calf delivered surgically is the mother's first. Does it have first-born offspring special status?

options.text: Yes; birth method doesn't matter.
No; only natural births count.

title: Setting aside a portion animals versus first-born offspring status
vignette: A farmer confuses livestock portions with first-born offspring obligations for his flock.

options.text: Keep them distinct; each has separate rules.
One process suffices for both.
